children.text: Okay, so I need to translate this Java code into Fortran.
children.label: language_mapping

children.text: Let me start by understanding what the Java code does.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: It's solving a problem, probably from AtCoder contest ABC150's D problem.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: The code reads two integers n and m, then reads n integers into array a. Then it processes them to compute the least common multiple (LCM) of certain values.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: First, in the main part, the code initializes an array a with n elements.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Each element of a is the input divided by 2. Wait, why divided by two?
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Maybe because the problem requires considering even numbers? Hmm, not sure yet but I'll proceed. The code then calculates the LCM of the elements in a. It uses a helper function getGCD to compute the GCD and then the LCM via the formula LCM(a,b)=a*b/GCD(a,b).
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: For each element in a, it updates the LCD (which is actually the LCM) step by step.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: If at any point LCD exceeds m, it outputs 0 and exits.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: That probably means any multiple beyond m can't count, so the answer is 0.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: Next, after computing the LCM, there's a loop checking each a[i] such that LCD divided by a[i] is even.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: If any of those are even, then output 0 and exit.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Maybe this ensures that each a[i] must divide LCD such that LCD/a[i] is odd?
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Not sure, but the logic is to check that.
children.label: empty

children.text: Finally, if all checks pass, the output is (m/LCD +1)/2.

The code would look like this:

program atcoder_ABC150_D

  implicit none

  integer(8) :: n, m, i
  integer(8), allocatable :: a(:)
  integer(8) :: lcm, gcd_val, current_a
  integer(8) :: result

  !
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Read Inputs
  read(*,*) n, m

  allocate(a(n)) do i = 1, n
     read(*,*) a(i)
     a(i) = a(i) / 2
  end do

  lcm = 1

  do i = 1, n
     gcd_val = getgcd(lcm, a(i))
     lcm = lcm * a(i) /
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
gcd_val
     if (lcm > m) then
        print *, 0
        deallocate(a)
        stop
     end if
  end do

  ! Now check for each term (lcm /a[i]) %2 ==0

  do i = 1, n
     if (mod( lcm / a(i), 2) ==0 ) then
        print *, 0
        deallocate(a)
        stop
     end if
  end do

  ! Output the formula
  result = (m / lcm +1 ) / 2
  print *, result

  deallocate(a)
  stop

contains

  recursive function getgcd( a,b ) result(res)
    integer(8), intent(in) :: a, b
    integer(8) :: res

    if (b ==0 ) then
       res = a
    else
       res = getgcd(b, mod(a,b))
children.label: code_analysis

end if
  end function getgcd

end program atcoder_ABC150_D

children.text:
In Fortran, once the executable code starts (i.e., the first executable line after declarations), you can not have declarations. So the code structure should be:

program ... 

  implicit none

  variable declarations here...

contains   (procedures)

  internal functions

end contain

then executable code. Wait no, the contain is at the end before procedures? Let me recall.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
The correct structure is:

program whatever
    implicit none
    declarations
    contains
    subroutine or function ...
    end function
    ... any others ...
    !
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: No, wait, the structure is: after the variable declarations, you can have the contains clause followed by the subprograms (functions, subroutines), then after that, the executable statements. So the code must be structured so that the contains comes after all variable declarations but before any of the executable statements.

program atcoder_ABC150_D

    implicit none

    integer(8) :: n, m, i, lcm, gcd_val, result
    integer(8), allocatable :: a(:)

    ! Declare internal functions first via contains
    contains

    recursive function getgcd(a, b) result(res)
        integer(8), intent(in) :: a, b
        integer(8) :: res

        if (b == 0) then
            res = a 
        else
            res = getgcd(b, mod(a, b))
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
end if
    end function getgcd

    ! Now the main code

    !

tree.original_reasoning:
Okay, so I need to translate this Java code into Fortran. Let me start by understanding what the Java code does. It's solving a problem, probably from AtCoder contest ABC150's D problem.

The code reads two integers n and m, then reads n integers into array a. Then it processes them to compute the least common multiple (LCM) of certain values. 

First, in the main part, the code initializes an array a with n elements. Each element of a is the input divided by 2. Wait, why divided by two? Maybe because the problem requires considering even numbers? Hmm, not sure yet but I'll proceed.

The code then calculates the LCM of the elements in a. It uses a helper function getGCD to compute the GCD and then the LCM via the formula LCM(a,b)=a*b/GCD(a,b). For each element in a, it updates the LCD (which is actually the LCM) step by step. If at any point LCD exceeds m, it outputs 0 and exits. That probably means any multiple beyond m can't count, so the answer is 0.

Next, after computing the LCM, there's a loop checking each a[i] such that LCD divided by a[i] is even. If any of those are even, then output 0 and exit. Maybe this ensures that each a[i] must divide LCD such that LCD/a[i] is odd? Not sure, but the logic is to check that.

Finally, if all checks pass, the output is (m/LCD +1)/2. Probably because the valid numbers are multiples of LCD, but compensated for the division by 2 earlier.

Now, translating this into Fortran. Let me note the differences between Java and Fortran here.

First, Fortran uses modules but maybe I don't need that here. The main program will be a program block. Arrays in Fortran are declared with dimensions, and are 1-based by default, but can be declared with a starting index. Since the Java code uses 0-based arrays, maybe I have to set the array index from 0 or adjust loops accordingly. Hmm, in Fortran, arrays typically start at 1 unless specified. So for variables like a in the code, which are declared as int[n], in Java they are from 0 to n-1. Therefore, in Fortran, I can declare a(n) with indices 1 to n, then adjust loops accordingly. Need to watch out for the loops.

Variables: Java has a Scanner class. In Fortran, we can use read(*,*) to get inputs. Since in Java the code reads n, then m, then n numbers, the Fortran code will do the same via read statements.

The GCD function: In Java it's a recursive method. Fortran can handle recursion, but sometimes people prefer loops. Here, the getGCD function is recursive, so in Fortran I need to create a function with recursion. The parameters would be integers or integers, but since the Java code uses long, maybe the Fortran version uses integers of larger kind (like 8 bytes) to handle big numbers. Since m could be up to what? Let's check problem constraints, but since it's translated, the code's original constraints must have been considered. The LCM might be very large, so variables should be 64-bit integers. So in Fortran, using integer(selected_int_kind(18)) variables perhaps, but I'll use kind=8 which is 64-bit on most systems.

So, for the variables n and m: in Java they're integers. Since in Fortran, they can be integers as well, unless m can be up to something very big. The output's formula (m/lcd) may need m and LCM to be 64-bit integers. Therefore, maybe using integer(kind=8) types for n, m, a array, gcd, and LCM.

Let's outline the steps:

Read n, m: in Fortran, read(*,*) n, m.

Then read an array a of n elements, each is input number divided by 2. So in Fortran:

allocate or declare an array of size n (since n is read dynamically). Wait, in Fortran 90 and later, you can have allocate-able arrays, but the Java code uses fixed n at the start, so maybe declare a as a(n) with explicit-shape. Hmm, but the size is known after reading n. Therefore better to read n first, then declare the array.

Wait, in Fortran, the variables have to be declared before they can be used. So, the code would need to read n first, then declare the array a with size n, then m. But in Fortran you can't have a declaration after the read unless using declarations in a way that allows it. Alternatively, use an allocatable array. Let me think:

The getgcd function is recursive. So in Fortran:

function getgcd(a, b) result(res)
   integer(kind=8), intent(in) :: a, b
   integer(kind=8) :: res

   if (b == 0) then

end function

So, the function getgcd must be defined before the main program. Wait, no, in Fortran, functions can be inside the program. Let me think: define an internal function.

Alternatively, I can have a function getgcd inside the program, as an internal function. The code would look like this:

program atcoder_ABC150_D

  implicit none

  integer(8) :: n, m, i
  integer(8), allocatable :: a(:)
  integer(8) :: lcm, gcd_val, current_a
  integer(8) :: result

  ! Read Inputs
  read(*,*) n, m

  allocate(a(n))

  do i = 1, n
     read(*,*) a(i)
     a(i) = a(i) / 2
  end do

  lcm = 1

  do i = 1, n
     gcd_val = getgcd(lcm, a(i))
     lcm = lcm * a(i) / gcd_val
     if (lcm > m) then
        print *, 0
        deallocate(a)
        stop
     end if
  end do

  ! Now check for each term (lcm /a[i]) %2 ==0

  do i = 1, n
     if (mod( lcm / a(i), 2) ==0 ) then
        print *, 0
        deallocate(a)
        stop
     end if
  end do

  ! Output the formula
  result = (m / lcm +1 ) / 2
  print *, result

  deallocate(a)
  stop

contains

  recursive function getgcd( a,b ) result(res)
    integer(8), intent(in) :: a, b
    integer(8) :: res

    if (b ==0 ) then
       res = a
    else
       res = getgcd(b, mod(a,b))
    end if
  end function getgcd

end program atcoder_ABC150_D

Wait in Fortran, the contain is followed by the procedure definitions (functions, etc), and then after that you can have the main program code. Wait, no, the contain comes after variables, but before the executable code. So code outline must be:

Thus, in the code outline:

The 'contains' block with the getGCD function comes after variables but before the executable statements.

So putting this all together, the program would be:

program atcoder_ABC150_D

    implicit none

    integer(8) :: n, m, i, lcm, gcd_val, result
    integer(8), allocatable :: a(:)

    ! Declare internal functions first via contains
    contains

    recursive function getgcd(a, b) result(res)
        integer(8), intent(in) :: a, b
        integer(8) :: res

        if (b == 0) then
            res = a 
        else
            res = getgcd(b, mod(a, b))
        end if
    end function getgcd

    ! Now the main code

    ! Read n and m
    read(*,*) n, m

    allocate(a(n))

    do i = 1, n
       read(*,*) a(i)
       a(i) = a(i) /2
    end do

    lcm = 1_8

    do i=1, n
        ! compute GCD of lcm and a(i)
        gcd_val = getgcd(lcm, a(i))
        lcm = lcm * a(i) / gcd_val

        ! Check if exceeds m
        if (lcm > m) then
            print *,0 
            deallocate(a)
            stop
        end if
    end do

    ! Check phase 2
    do i =1, n
        if (mod( lcm / a(i), 2) ==0 ) then
            print *,0
            deallocate(a)
            stop
        end if
    end do

    ! output
    result = (m / lcm +1 ) /2 
    print *, result

    deallocate(a)
    stop

end program atcoder_ABC150_D
